content: I hadn't meant to get drawn in this deep into the study of [[heaps]], but some people are posing nice conjectures about them after I posted about them on Mastodon, so I feel a duty to record those conjectures.

First, while I believe the category of heaps is equivalent to the category of group-torsor pairs, there are some questions about the nature of the latter category: what it actually is, and whether it can be defined using the Grothendieck construction.

I think the category of group-torsor pairs, say Tors\mathsf{Tors}Tors, works like this:

  • an object (G,H)(G,H)(G,H) is a group GGG together with a GGG-torsor HHH, i.e. a nonempty set HHH equipped with a free and transitive GGG-action.
  • a morphism (ϕ,f):(G,H)→(G′,H′)(\phi, f) : (G,H) \to (G',H')(ϕ,f):(G,H)→(G′,H′) is a group homomorphism ϕ:G→G′\phi: G \to G'ϕ:G→G′ and a set map f:H→H′f: H \to H'f:H→H′ such that f(gh)=ϕ(g)f(h) f(gh) = \phi(g) f(h) f(gh)=ϕ(g)f(h) for all g∈Gg \in Gg∈G, h∈Hh \in Hh∈H.

It would be nice to verify that this really is equivalent to the category of heaps as claimed in the nLab article [[heap]]. There shouldn't be anything very hard about checking this.

But then there's the question of how this category Tors\mathsf{Tors}Tors is related to all the categories GTorsG \mathsf{Tors}GTors of GGG-torsors. In GTorsG \mathsf{Tors}GTors

  • an object is a GGG-torsor HHH and
  • a morphism f:H→H′f: H \to H'f:H→H′ is a set map such that f(gh)=gf(h)f(g h) = g f(h)f(gh)=gf(h).

LeeMph raised this question:

Question. Is there a pseudofunctor from Grp\mathsf{Grp}Grp to Cat\mathsf{Cat}Cat sending each group GGG to the category GTorsG \mathsf{Tors}GTors, either covariant or contravariant, such that performing the Grothendieck construction stitches together all the category GTorsG \mathsf{Tors}GTors to form the category Tors\mathsf{Tors}Tors?

We discussed it a while, and his latest verdict is negative, but he thinks something a bit fancier will work. So a better version of the question above may be:

Question. How exactly can we get Tors\mathsf{Tors}Tors from all the categories GTorsG \mathsf{Tors}GTors?

By the way, if anyone had the insane amount of energy necessary to do this, it would be nice to investigate this in a general topos, since the concept of 'torsor' becomes very interesting then: it more or less subsumes the concept of [[principal bundle]], which is very important in geometry.
Indeed maybe someone has already studied it at that level of generality!

Here are some potential directions (which I did not have time to check thoroughly yet, but just wanted to share some intuitions as I have to go):

  • can we define a GGG-torsor as a functor TG→SetT_G \to \mathbf{Set}TG​→Set where TGT_GTG​ is the limit sketch (Lawvere theory?) made of Cartesian products GnG^{n}Gn and group homomorphism between them?
  • (if yes then) denoting Mod(TG)↪[TG,Set] \mathsf{Mod}(T_G) \hookrightarrow [T_G,\mathbf{Set}]Mod(TG​)↪[TG​,Set] the reflective subcategory restricted to limit preserving functors, is the mapping T:G↦Mod(TG)\mathcal{T}:G \mapsto \mathsf{Mod}(T_G)T:G↦Mod(TG​) a functor Grp→Cat\mathsf{Grp} \to \mathbf{Cat}Grp→Cat (or Grpop→Cat\mathsf{Grp} ^{\mathsf{op}}\to \mathbf{Cat}Grpop→Cat)?
  • (if yes then) is Tors\mathsf{Tors}Tors the Grothendieck construction of T\mathcal{T}T?

Second - sorry, I'm just plowing ahead here before I forget - there's the question of what's the free group on a heap. There's a forgetful functor

U:Grp→HeapU : \mathsf{Grp} \to \mathsf{Heap} U:Grp→Heap

sending any group GGG to the underlying set of GGG made into a heap with operation t(a,b,c)=ab−1ct(a,b,c) = a b^{-1} ct(a,b,c)=ab−1c. This must have a left adjoint (by general nonsense about Lawvere theories), so:

Question. Concretely as possible, what is the left adjoint of U:Grp→HeapU : \mathsf{Grp} \to \mathsf{Heap} U:Grp→Heap?

And Oscar Cunningham proposed an answer. First, recall that there's a functor

Str:Heap→Grp \mathrm{Str}: \mathsf{Heap} \to \mathsf{Grp} Str:Heap→Grp

sending any heap HHH to the group of all maps h↦t(a,b,h)h \mapsto t(a,b,h)h↦t(a,b,h) from HHH to itself, where a,ba,ba,b are arbitrary elements of HHH. (If we think of a heap as a group-torsor pair, this functor picks out the group in that pair.)

I foolishly ventured that the left adjoint of U:Grp→HeapU : \mathsf{Grp} \to \mathsf{Heap}U:Grp→Heap was this functor Str\mathsf{Str}Str, but Oscar improved that guess:

Conjecture. The left adjoint of U:Grp→HeapU : \mathsf{Grp} \to \mathsf{Heap}U:Grp→Heap sends any heap HHH to the group Z∗Str(H)\mathbb{Z} \ast \mathsf{Str}(H)Z∗Str(H), where ∗\ast∗ is the "free product", or coproduct, of groups.

He motivated this with a nice analogy: the left adjoint of the forgetful functor from real vector spaces to affine spaces takes any affine space Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn to Rn+1\mathbb{R}^{n+1}Rn+1, where the extra dimension arises from freely putting in an origin.

@John Baez This is an abuse of language on my part and my fault for trying to go too fast. I usually see a limit sketch as a pair (C,L)(C, L)(C,L) where CCC is a small category and LLL is a set of cones in CCC. Here, I define a cone as a natural transformation of the form ΔI(X)⇒F\Delta_I(X) \Rightarrow FΔI​(X)⇒F where:

  • III is a small category,
  • XXX is an object in CCC,
  • Δ:C→[I,C]\Delta: C \to [I, C]Δ:C→[I,C] is the obvious constant functor,
  • F:I→CF: I \to CF:I→C is a functor.

If all the small categories III associated with the cones in LLL are discrete categories, then I would tend to call (C,L)(C, L)(C,L) a product sketch.

I define a model for a limit sketch as a functor M:C→SetM: C \to \mathbf{Set}M:C→Set sending every cone a:ΔI(X)⇒Fa:\Delta_I(X) \Rightarrow Fa:ΔI​(X)⇒F in LLL to a limit cone M(a):ΔI(M(X))⇒M∘FM(a):\Delta_I(M(X)) \Rightarrow M \circ FM(a):ΔI​(M(X))⇒M∘F in Set\mathbf{Set}Set.

While this is one definition, there are other common definitions for limit sketches. For instance, one might assume that the cones in LLL must be limit cones in CCC. In that case, the models send the limit cones in LLL to limit cones in Set\mathsf{Set}Set.

Based on my experience and interactions, I usually prefer to use the term limit-preserving to evoke the idea that these functors send the "equipped (synthetic) limits" to limits in Set\mathbf{Set}Set, avoiding potential confusion with the various meanings of "model". But in this case, that did not help me much with the clarity :upside_down:

(Also, I would love to hear how others define limit sketches so I can feel more comfortable with the terminology)

Nathan Corbyn said:

I’m confused why you need to go through finite limit sketches. If Mod(TG)\mathrm{Mod}(T_G)Mod(TG​) is supposed to be equivalent to G−TorG\mathrm{-Tor}G−Tor, what stops you from defining the functor as mapping GGG to G−TorG\mathrm{-Tor}G−Tor directly?

That's a good point, and I see where you are coming from. But given why we are interested in GGG-torsors, I think it is useful to first understand them as models for limit sketches. Heaps can also be seen as models for limit sketches pretty straightforwardly (same with groups). Plus, if you check out the nLab page on [[heaps]], you will see that converting GGG-torsors to heaps and back mostly involves playing around with operations, hinting at deeper theoretical connections (as in theory for models).

If we are going to talk about the yoga of techniques that let us switch between them, I would rather get the big picture in the same language. That is why I lean towards limit sketches -- they would set the stage for understanding how groups, torsors, and heaps all fit together with their left adjoints.

And maybe I should add that limit sketches are a very natural language to build those left adjoints, even giving us formulas, often useful for end, co-end and transfinite calculi.

For anyone interested in the topic, see Categories of continuous functors, I as a starting point.

I haven’t checked this carefully but I think it’s true that G−Tors≃BGG\mathrm{-Tors} \simeq \mathbf{B}GG−Tors≃BG. There’s a fully faithful functor from the delooping to torsors coming from taking GGG’s action on itself (Yoneda lemma) and (assuming torsors are assumed to be non-empty) then every tosor admits an isomorphism with GGG as a set. The bit I haven’t checked is whether this isomorphism can always be made into an equivariant map.

In which case, we’re really talking about the functor B:Grp→Cat\mathbf{B} : \mathrm{Grp} \to \mathrm{Cat}B:Grp→Cat sending each group to its delooping and how this compares to Tors\mathrm{Tors}Tors.

Question. Concretely as possible, what is the left adjoint of U:Grp→Heap?

And Oscar Cunningham proposed an answer.

The answer Oscar gave is the answer I would have given (without trying too hard to be concrete). In general, if you have monads G,HG, HG,H on a category C\mathbf{C}C with reflexive coequalizers, with a monad morphism ϕ:H→G\phi: H \to Gϕ:H→G, and CG→CH\mathbf{C}^G \to \mathbf{C}^HCG→CH denotes the forgetful functor between the categories of algebras that is induced by the monad morphism, then the left adjoint to this forgetful functor takes an HHH-algebra XXX to the coequalizer of a pair of arrows

GHX⇉GλρXGX.GHX \overset{\rho X}{\underset{G\lambda}{\rightrightarrows}} GX.GHXGλ⇉​ρX​GX.

This is just like the situation for writing down the tensor product of a right RRR-module YYY with a left RRR-module XXX, as a coequalizer:

Y⊗R⊗X⇉Y⊗X→Y⊗RXY \otimes R \otimes X \rightrightarrows Y \otimes X \to Y \otimes_R XY⊗R⊗X⇉Y⊗X→Y⊗R​X.

Only this time, HHH acts on GGG on the right by a composite GH→GϕGG→μGGH \overset{G\phi}{\to} GG \overset{\mu}{\to} GGH→GϕGG→μG, and on the left on an HHH-algebra XXX by the algebra structure λ:HX→X\lambda: HX \to Xλ:HX→X.

Think for example of the way that the universal enveloping algebra of a Lie algebra works: by taking a certain quotient of the tensor algebra (which plays the role of GXGXGX). Oscar's proposal is working exactly the same way.

Nathan Corbyn said:

I haven’t checked this carefully but I think it’s true that G−Tors≃BGG\mathrm{-Tors} \simeq \mathsf{B}GG−Tors≃BG

Yes, that's true. From one point of view the point of torsors is to take BG\mathsf{B}GBG, which has one object and one morphism for each element of GGG, and find an equivalent category with objects that are sets with extra structure - namely GGG-torsors - and structure-preserving maps between them. It gives a new and fruitful outlook.
